subject: Re: New to JUnit
msgSnippet: ... Hi Johannes, Thanks for your reply. My TreeHolder class is something like this: // Note: MyNode implements MutableTreeNode interface // and holds a
messageBody:
--- In junit@y..., Johannes Link <john.link@g...> wrote:
> With which part of your TreeHolder functionality have you testing
> problems? The build up or the state changes?
> Can you share (at least part of) your code base, so that we can more
> easily grasp the exact semantics?
>
> Johannes
>

Hi Johannes,
Thanks for your reply. My TreeHolder class is something like this:

// Note: MyNode implements MutableTreeNode interface
// and holds a UserDefinedObject

public class TreeHolder {

MyNode rootNode; //the root node for the whole tree

public TreeHolder(Collection items) {
//constructor logic to build MyNodes out of the input
//items and set rootNode as the root of the generated
//tree of MyNodes.

rootNode = ... //build a MyNode Tree From "items"
}

public void calculateSomething(int contextValue) {

//This changes the state of some MyNodes in the tree
rootNode.calculateSomething(contextValue);
}

//.... several such calculate methods

public void summarizeAll() {

//This again changes the state in some other way.
rootNode.summarizeAll();
}

public MyPackagedObject getAsNewPacakgedObject() {

//This packages the MyNode tree into a flattened
//object and returns it.

return rootNode.newPackagedObject();
}
}

I have written TestCases for the MyNode object already. Every
calculate method on TreeHolder changes the state of the rootNode (or
one/many subnodes.) So, how do I go about testing if the state
changes are correct? Or rather, should I even be writing them (since
TestMyNode may already covers those cases?)

Thanks in advance for your help.
--Das
